review_title: Clone Office, poor management- you can do better
pros: Can work from home in some jobs
cons: Really poor management- managers are like robots and so ‘by the book’ that they would probably come to work naked if that is what the book says. Management are really sycophantic towards the vice chancellor and also petrified of him, so do not expect any true leaders. My office (CAMS) is basically a clone office, all new starters fit the same demographics, if you are over 40 then don’t bother applying, you won’t get the job. HR are useless, they are aware of all the favouritism yet do very little to prevent it. There’s no incentives for loyalty, staff members with longer time worked are passed for training/ promotion in favour of young workers who have barely done anything in their job.

review_title: Don't work in Marketing at NTU
pros: Easy work, average pay, okay annual leave
cons:
I've never known a marketing department to be as dysfunctional as this, it's laughable. If you take pride in your job and work ethic avoid working here. You won't be rewarded for knowledge, skills and performance, as at the end of the day it's completely who you know, not what you know.

After a completely abysmal and unnecessary restructure - all of the wrong people have earned promotions with less work to do. Therefore, they will ignore any feedback and ideas for improvements as it's not in their interests to improve things. If you politely raise any issues (and even offer useful solutions) you will be labelled as a 'problem'. The distribution of workload is absolutely laughable, some colleagues have about 10x the workload of others on a higher salary!

If you love to play the social game and take credit for others work, NTU is the place for you!

review_title: Not a good place in which to build your career
pros: The university is strongly committed to sustainability, as reflected in their green policies and cycle to work scheme.  For the most part, supportive and friendly colleagues.
cons: The university is a very toxic and undemocratic place to work. Every year, new policies and procedures are imposed from above with no prior consultation with staff. There are several layers of management, who do not provide support for staff and many of whom are incompetent and not professional (there have also been several cases of bullying).  Expect your workload to continually increase, once again without negotiation. All offices are shared for academic staff, and some staff are stuffed like battery hens in overcrowded offices with as much as six or more people.  Very little support for research is given and teaching workloads are not fairly and equitably distributed- there is a lot of favouritism. Turnover is high as a result. In short, only come here if you are really desperate!

pros: flexible, helpful, opportunity for growth
cons: no cons to do with this job

pros: at this stage i really have noting positive to say
cons:
The culture of bullying, and the nepotism is disgraceful. 

Worst of all is the attitude towards mental health. people forced out of the position because of mental health issues. Zero understanding. Zero empathy  and proactively seeking to fire people with mental health issues (this has happened on multiple occasions) 

Gang culture means unless you are in the clique - you are going nowhere. 
People promoted into positions with absolutely no skill set to do so. 

People put into jobs that are not advertised to all staff. 

Interviews are made about specific subjects  - not about  job description or person spec. People (friends of clique) are hand picked for the role are then given information regarding the very specific questions for interview, this means other people going for the role do not stand a chance. People with none of the job requirements , skills, knowledge or experience put into roles as they "interviewed well" - of course they did, you made the interview about a subject you have fed to them..?!?! 
 
People in the office (who are highly skilled, but are not friends with clique) are now not bothering applying for roles as "we know who is going to get that". 

People leave and do not complain as they are so deflated

pros: Good company to work for
cons: Some processes are beurocratic and difficult

pros: Excellent campus and friendly, knowledgable colleagues. Good facilities and equipment to use when available.  Easy access to campus
cons:
Everything really.
Technical department suffers from rigamortis, there pace can only be likened to what is called reverse gear.
Estates more interested in changing a light bulb than anything more difficult. This is so they can tick off their job sheets and make it look like they have done more work than they actually have. They also have their own bedrooms set up in derilict parts of the uni so they can have their afternoon sleep.
Lecturer recruitment, what a joke, they are more interested in recruiting someone with 30000 pounds worth of funding even when they can't speak English very well. How much dothe students pay now, a typical class could be paying a million to the uni in a year but they don't care.
Academics on over 1000 pound a week with no research and cannot hardly speak English, the students are getting a rough deal here.
Paying people over 40000 a year to sign a piece of paper every few hours.
The whole place is generally mad, everyone in their own little universe, feathering their own nest, majority just want do minimum to get by.
I advise anyone wanting to study here. DONT

review_title: My Thoughtful Review of Work at NTU
job_title: Student Placement In Science and Technology Department in Nottingham, England
pros:
You are well paid on time no delays:)
You get to work in a very comfortable environment
You get to engage with staffs who are well educated and skilled in their work
Sure to have a good career advice from the school's employability team regarding your work, to me is brilliant!!
cons: Task could be very repetitive..but could be better if proper review is made from time to time and a little tweak is done to make task given at work more exciting.

pros:
-Emotions rarely ignored.
-Won't ever have to do Over-time, similar to public sector in that people just do their shift and go home - bad if you're wanting to progress or change the "just how we do it" approach taken by the majority of staff.
-Will be promoted for simply being at the company the longest.
cons:
-Hierarchy evident in the way people speak to each other.
-Overheard manager stating they would have rather hired someone from the other sex if they could, "but oh well" (On my first day!)
-Managers typically behind on the knowledge gap in comparison to their teams, leads to issues not being addressed/understood.

review_title: Committed, student focused staff, but pressurising, short-sighted, and opaque management = disappointing failure
pros: The academic and administrative staff are generally very committed to students and student welfare, and generally very friendly.  Many are very intelligent and very generous with their time, and will often step in to assist you if you reciprocate. In previous years, many Business School staff had spent significant time in industry and the professions, had a good working style, were down-to-earth and integrated new staff.  Work life balance has been generally reasonable, although exam marking is always a fraught period.  Business school staff have free tea and coffee. There have been some genuinely great innovations by staff in courses, teaching, learning and research.  Remuneration is slightly ahead of similar institutions. Collegiality within departments is generally very good.  General IT resources are good, although sometimes technical support is not always forthcoming. There are some great architectural buildings, and some great places to teach.
cons:
The emphasis on "business style" management in recent years is stifling, imposing several expensive and unproductive management layers, and has promulgated some dubious practices. Senior Management approaches to HR relations are a caricature of a poor 1970-80's manufacturing industrial case study, rather than enlightened practices for 21st century knowledge workers. Good quality, transparent leadership is lacking. Promotions appear to be determined on your face fitting with management, rather than on capability to achieve outcomes. Pressure to inflate grades is also high.

The business school was a good school with inventive teaching and some credible researchers. However, many academic staff with excellent industrial knowledge and connections have left, to the detriment of standards. These industrially astute staff are rarely replaced because of recruitment policies requiring applicants to have research backgrounds, rather than industrial capability and teaching ability. This has resulted in the recruitment of several career academics without business experience (often new, young, international PHDs), perhaps to the detriment of graduate employability, and probably contributing to staff turnover rates as they leave after a couple of years. The reason behind the recruitment policy change is the pursuit of often unachievable international 'badges' by school managers, mainly due to their misunderstanding of the school's unique selling points; management style often focuses on (perceived) activity rather than actual achievement. This propagates reactionary change projects which are often detrimental to both staff morale and ability to do the day-to-day work of teaching and research. Accommodation for business school staff is an unsatisfying compromise between open plan and academic team-shared offices, where one often tumbles over colleagues or (if one is portly as I am) is a disturbing squeeze past co-workers in an attempt to exit. Even professors must share accommodation.

Disappointingly, what was once a great place to work as a solid teaching institution with great industrial & local links, and credible research, has now become a stressful, pressurised, place to do a job with weaker teaching, poorer local industrial links and only marginally better research.

review_title: Allowed me to discover my potential and skills I didn't know I had.
pros: Good people - caring colleagues - change and challenges are common, can be rewarding, and develop skills.
cons: Changing times in the HE sector would make it difficult to know what or how things may develop in the short- to long-term.

review_title: Great colleagues but a very difficult place to produce high quality research
pros: Generous annual leave entitlement and remuneration. Friendly and knowledgeable colleagues. Pleasant, quiet campus (Clifton). Spending on new buildings.
cons: University management. Reactionary managment style - action only taken when a problem develops. Purchasing department. Precious few permanent roles if you initially start on a fixed-term contract. No continuity of teaching staff - happy to let experienced lecturers leave without a second thought.

pros: Reasonably good salary.  Easy job.
cons:
Working til 11pm!!!!!  Waiting 7 weeks for initial salary (bank staff) - most people would not be able to wait that long.
Breathtaking unfairness in the way it is run - favouritism rules.  Some bank staff are working almost full time, while others are on little or NO hours.  Some are told that no hours are available, when there are - they are just allocated to the favoured few employees.  Management take 8 weeks off (yes - 2 months!) and then raise the fact that you had 1 day (yes, 1 day!) off sick.  Now you see what i mean by 'breathtaking unfairness'.

pros:
Working on your own
Working in a team
cons:
Overfriendly
Unorganised
Other staff don't do their work

review_title: People are great but management is poor
pros:
High salary
Committed and knowledgable colleagues
Good facilities
cons: Poor leadership and management at middle and senior levels. Lack of management competence and good role models. Proliferation of self serving managers who are able to manipulate those above them who lack the ability to actually deliver in any of their promises.

review_title: Working in the NTU Brackenhurst Library
pros: This is a lovely, peaceful place to work.  However, it is also dynamic and technical, with a huge range of resources, both online, and in physical form.  The staff are great, and really helpful (that is my experience of being a student at this campus, too).
cons: The work that I do is part-time, so it is not enough on its own to sustain me financially.  However, if there was a full-time position available, I would take it!

pros: Good workers, you meet many people who live NTU and care about its values. Unfortunately they are not...
cons: Management who are incompetent, don’t give clear orders, don’t practice what they preach, are over paid,  hypocritical, sycophantic ‘yes people’  who base their management style on having seen a couple of episodes of ‘the Apprentice’.

pros:
Interesting and varied work, exciting to be part of projects pushing research areas forward. 
Friendly culture.
cons: Appalling job security. Contracts for most research staff are extended for a maximum of 3 months at a time, and often won't find out if it's being extended or not up to a week before it runs out.

pros: Really enjoyed working here. Sim crealltvnuce people and the salary was good. I would go back if I could.
cons: As above I had a great time working here and only left because I had my young children to look after.

pros: I am able to work the hours that fit around my studies, everyone is really friendly and gets stuck in with anything that needs doing. Our management team are fab, and exteremly fair with all team members.
cons: Some of the hours are unsociable.

pros: Holiday entitlement is above average. There are some good people there, but they are being let down by unrealistic expectations and a focus on league tables.
cons: Professional services staff are treated appallingly. Leadership team rule through ego, fear, control and micro management. Staff are simply treated as delivery units. There is no respect for professional expertise from leadership and academic depts.

review_title: Great company to work in, good flexible benefits and supportive team members.
job_title: Environmental Engagement Assistant in Nottingham, England
pros:
Engaging staff to work alongside,
Flexible benefits,
Sustainable reputation,
Central location,
Great transport links,
Stimulating environment,
Constant new research is being conducted through the university.
cons:
Some of the staff only buildings are very old fashioned and not the easiest to work in.
Communication between different departments/teams is also quite poor.

review_title: Quick growth but without supporting your employees to grow
pros: Pension and annual leave allowance
cons: Pressure on delivery and no support. No clear strategy and consistent implementation. Lack of training and allowance for skills development. No chance to progress your career, once employed in a role, you can stay in it forever.

pros: Good benefits, lovely people, and good career development. There is also a lot of support for staff such as flexible working and wellbeing.
cons: Entry level jobs (graduate level) jobs don't come up all too often unless for maternity cover.

job_title: Student Services Centre Customer Adviser in Nottingham, England
pros:
- Supervisors and managers are encouraged to support staff growth.
- Excellent benefits such as cheaper bus cards, gym memberships etc.
cons: - Not much in terms of upward progression; competition is fierce and you will often compete with both internal and external applicants for a position.

pros: I worked with lecturers in designing, conducting and collecting data for a research project. The lecturers were very clear about what were my responsibilities and made sure I was comfortable in expressing my criticisms and suggestions for the project.
cons: I cannot think of any cons

job_title: School Management Administrator in Nottingham, England
pros:
Great Team 
everyone is really laid back
great training courses
great HR communication 
great information systems
cons: Undervalued some staff get treated better than others by the manager

pros: Autonomy, atmosphere, great colleagues, good physical environment, an innovative university with a sense of momentum.
cons: Heavy workload, trying to do too much making it hard to prioritise tasks.

pros: friendly work environment, many holidays (question is: when can you take them), flexible working time (surely, you have to be on time for lectures).
cons: not research focused, though research is kind of supported, but no additional time is allocated.

pros: Management was fantastic; Training was provided with patience and encouragement; very high standards of service; brilliant remuneration for a graduate position
cons: only fixed term (6 months)

review_title: The money is good and the work is interesting
pros: The money is good and the work is interesting, especially research fields.
cons: Dealing with IT and Admin makes you want to blow your brains out.

pros: Strong leadership from the senior team, excellent work environment, supportive management for flexible working arrangements.
cons: I don't have many cons - I have been there for just over a year.

pros: Great team menber to work with
cons: Management to focused on administration  thus preventing staff from getting the job done

pros: Reasonable pay compared to other places
cons: No perks no staff room minimal staffing noisy/hot/ cramped working environment

pros:
Contemporary and leading edge business school
Immaculate facilities and industrial connections
cons: Curriculum is a modern twist on traditional economics disciplines

review_title: Great University that provides plenty of support
pros: Great library, excellent support from the information desk, good timetables, plenty of time for revision.
cons: The PPD module isn't that engaging.

pros: Great experience, looks good on cv and great to get to know other people!
cons: A lot of other people take on the job

pros: fantastic working environment, excellent development opportunities, good balance of responsibility and guidance
cons: I have nothing negative to comment, everything during my year was brilliant!

pros: Great uni and social life, highly recommend
cons: not too many bad points, very good university

pros:

review_title: NTU is best place to work

cons: Restricted on car park but accessible with public transport.

pros: Easy job, fun to interact with all the students and families, get given a hot lunch.

pros: Annual leave and no requirement to do long hours

pros: Great pension, that's about it.
